MICHAEL LEMON, M.ED., M.S., 2022  All Rights Reserved      5 Abstract  Despite recent advances in legal protections for and increases in social acceptability towards LGBTQ+ individuals, they continue to experience widespread prejudice and discrimination and seek therapy more often than their heterosexual counterparts as a result. As more and more LGBTQ+ people sought out therapeutic services, psychological research in the field of LGBTQ+ affirming therapy began to develop in order to meet these needs. Although the number of articles and studies conducted in this field has grown exponentially since the start of the 21st century, a sizeable gap between research and application remains. Research often provides vague suggestions without discussing specific clinical recommendations. Until discussion shifts to emphasize the practical aspect of LGBTQ+ affirming therapy, the mental health needs of this large and diverse group of people will not be met. Therefore, the major goal of this project is to review the intersection of mental health and LGBTQ+ people over time and conclude with specific recommendations for providing LGBTQ+ affirmative care across a variety of presenting concerns and treatment settings. It is worth noting that LGBTQ+ affirming therapy is not a specific theoretical orientation or form of treatment on its own. Rather, it is a way of providing therapeutic treatment that takes into consideration the history of LGBTQ+ individuals, the impact of intersectionality, unique individual experiences, and affirms that nobody is less than anybody else, regardless of their sexual identity and/or gender identity. The cultural identities of our clients should be praised, encouraged, and used to inform how we provide mental health services. These conditions represent the heart of LGBTQ+ affirming therapy, which has the potential to have a significant positive impact on countless individuals who need our help as clinicians.   6 Dedication This project is dedicated first and foremost to my late father, Doug Lemon, for the love, care, and knowledge he provided me with in my personal, academic, and professional lives. Introduction Introduction of the Topic  The LGBTQ+ community has a centuries-long history of facing discrimination, prejudice, victimization, and incarceration across the world. Only in the past few decades have LGBTQ+ individuals received increased legal protections and the right to marriage across much of the developed world. During this period of time, there has also been a significant increase in support from non-LGBTQ+ people across the world. However, these positive changes do not erase the significant difficulties that LGBTQ+ individuals experience in all areas of their lives, including academic, social, occupational, familial, emotional, and physical functioning (Godfrey et al., 2006). In fact, Gender and Sexual Minority (GSM) people are significantly more likely to seek out mental health treatment than heterosexual and cisgender individuals (Hinrichs & Donaldson, 2017). Exacerbating their mental health concerns is the fact that many GSM individuals encounter significant barriers to seeking and receiving treatment of their emotional, mental, and physical health (Smalley et al., 2018). These barriers exist at the individual, environmental, and systemic levels. Individual barriers include discrimination in health care, lack of comprehensive health coverage, lack of information about available services, negative past experiences, and beliefs that clinicians will be homo/transphobic (Ross et al., 2007; Smalley et al., 2018). At the environmental level, GSM individuals experience a lack of legal nondiscrimination protections at the local, state, and federal levels and also do not see themselves represented in clinical spaces, be it in clinician materials or in a lack of neutral bathroom spaces (Smalley et al., 2018). Systemically, LGBTQ+ individuals often encounter a lack of competent clinicians, resources, research, and data (Smalley et al.,   10 2018). As a result of these struggles and barriers, it is crucial that mental health providers actively work to solve these problems and provide competent and affirming care to their LGBTQ+ clients through every step of the therapeutic process.  Definition of the Problem  Since the LGBTQ+ community experiences mental health concerns and seeks out mental health care at significantly higher rates than heterosexual and cisgender individuals (Cochran, 2001; Cooley, 1998; Hinrichs & Donaldson, 2017), it is imperative that mental health clinicians receive training and education that allows them to serve their GSM clients in a competent, supportive, and caring way. In addition to lack of competency, a major barrier to seeking mental health services is the fact that the field of mental health has a long history of harming and shaming LGBTQ+ individuals by pathologizing and attempting to convert their minority sexual identities (Clarke et al., 2010; Davies & Neal, 1996; Shidlo & Gonsiorek, 2017). In addition to emphasizing LGBTQ+ education within training programs, it is essential to provide clinicians with specific recommendations so they can implement LGBTQ+ affirming therapy into their clinical work with ALL clients. If these conditions are met, the end goal of reducing mental health symptoms and improving overall quality of life for GSM people can be achieved.  Statement of Significance  Learning to work effectively with LGBTQ+ clients is crucial to being a well-rounded, multiculturally-informed, and ethically sound clinician. One’s ability to work well with LGBTQ+ clients is significant (American Psychological Association; APA, 2009). A study conducted by the APA (2009) found that out of over 2,500 clinicians who   11 were surveyed, 99% reported working with at least one LGBTQ+ client during their careers. In addition, LGBTQ+ individuals have a distinct culture and their own unique strengths and challenges as a result of their lived experiences (APA, 2009). LGBTQ+ individuals are more likely to endorse symptoms of psychological distress and are more likely to seek out therapeutic services than heterosexual and cisgender individuals (Hinrichs & Donaldson, 2017). In addition, LGBTQ+ individuals deal with life stressors and social stigma that heterosexual and cisgender individuals do not, including living in a homophobic society, coming out to loved ones, difficulties in adopting children, and a lack of religious and familial support (Godfrey et al., 2006).   Even if clients are motivated and able to seek out therapeutic services, they often experience discrimination, invalidation, and homophobia when working with clinicians. Nystrom (1997) found that 46% of LGBTQ+ clients had worked with homophobic clinicians and 34% had worked with clinicians who refused to acknowledge their LGBTQ+ identities as legitimate. Finally, the current project is significant because it is one of few (if not the only) project that directly discusses conversion therapy, LGBTQ+ affirming therapy, intersectionality as it pertains to LGBTQ+ individuals, the importance of clinician training, the process of coming out, and that provides clear recommendations for utilizing LGBTQ+ affirming therapy in clinical practice.  Purpose  The first purpose of the current project is to discuss the history of LGBTQ+ mental health treatment in order to establish context and the need for LGBTQ+ affirming care. This begins with a history of conversion therapy and a discussion of its effects and early research studies that praised its importance and efficacy. Another purpose is to   12 provide an overview of what LGBTQ+ affirming therapy is, what it means at a theoretical level, how intersectionality plays a role in it, how minority stress impacts LGBTQ+ mental health, and ways that it can be used in working with clients through the coming out process. Another purpose is to establish the importance of clinician education in working with GSM clients. The final and perhaps most important purpose of this project is to provide clinicians and students with specific practical recommendations for using LGBTQ+ affirming therapy in their own clinical work across a wide array of presenting concerns and treatment settings. Ideally, readers will come away with a historical understanding of the intersection between the LGBTQ+ community and the field of mental health, an idea of what LGBTQ+ affirming therapy means and looks like, and a more specific idea of what LGBTQ+ affirming therapy looks like from a clinical practice standpoint so that they can effectively treat mental health concerns for their GSM clients.               13 II. Literature Review & Conversion Therapy Method of Conducting Literature Review  Articles were collected using the Academic Search Ultimate and PsycINFO databases via Eastern Kentucky University’s library website. The keywords that were chosen to collect articles included “LGBT,” “LGBTQ,” “Conversion Therapy,” “Ex-Gay Movement,” “Affirming Therapy,” “LGBT Affirming Therapy,” “Effects of Conversion Therapy,” “Effects of Affirming Therapy,” “intersectionality,” and “affirming therapy techniques.” Additionally, three textbooks were utilized as part of this literature review, and they are listed in the References section.  History of Conversion Therapy In order to better understand the context within which conversion therapy was born, it is important to consider the history of the LGBTQ+ movement and what most of the world’s views were on non-heterosexual individuals. Until the past few decades, it was not uncommon to hear of LGBTQ+ individuals being tortured for the purpose of experiments or simply out of spite. For example, the Nazis experimented on gay men who were held in their concentration camps during World War II (Davies & Neal, 1996). In the United States during the late 1940s through the early 1960s, a major purge of LGBTQ+ people from the State Department led to thousands of people being fired from their jobs (Blakemore, 2019). This mass exodus is now known as the Lavender Scare. Historians believe the Lavender Scare was part of a larger pushback against the quickly growing underground gay culture that began as cities grew after the end of World War II. In 1953, President Dwight D. Eisenhower signed Executive Order 10450, “Security Requirements for Government Employment,” which indicated that “sexual perversion”   14 was a fair reason to terminate a person’s employment (Blakemore, 2019, para. 10). As a result of this harrowing order, several LGBTQ+ government employees died by suicide (Blakemore, 2019). It was not until 1995, when Bill Clinton signed Executive Order 12968, that the government was officially barred from discriminating against employees based on sexual identity (National Counterintelligence and Security Center, n.d.).  Although the fields of psychology and psychiatry are forward-thinking today, they were not as progressive when it came to conceptualizing LGBTQ+ individuals until the 1970s. In the United States, the American Psychiatric Association’s (APA) handbook for diagnosis, the Diagnostic Statistical Manual (DSM), being homosexual was considered a “sociopathic personality” (Forstein, 2001, p. 169) starting in 1952. This  label not only communicated that homosexuality was a disorder, but it also suggested that it was “inherently dangerous to society at large” (Forstein, 2001, p. 169). It was not until 1973 that homosexuality was removed from the second edition of the DSM (Davies & Neal, 1996). Even later, the World Health Organization’s version of the DSM, the International Classification of Diseases (ICD) considered homosexuality to be a mental disorder until 1992 (Davies & Neal, 1996). In 1994, the APA conducted a study of psychiatrists across the world and found that the majority of psychiatrists in Belarus, Brazil, China, India, Poland, Romania, Spain, and Venezuela “still considered homosexuality an illness” (Forstein, 2001, p. 170).  In terms of theoretical underpinnings, psychoanalysis, behavior therapy, CBT, hypnosis, eye-movement desensitization and reprocessing, psychotropic medications, couples therapy, family therapy, group therapy, inpatient psychiatric interventions, surgical interventions, fasting, praying, exorcism, and religious counseling have all been   15 used as conversion therapy (Butler, 2010; Flentje et al., 2014; Forstein, 2001; Haldeman, 2002; Shidlo & Gonsiorek, 2017). In order to gain a sense of credibility, conversion therapy utilizes a pseudo-scientific theoretical base that is not empirically supported (Shidlo & Gonsiorek, 2017). In addition to concerns surrounding interventions utilized in conversion therapy, the most common providers of conversion therapy were clergymen and very few were psychologists, psychiatrists, or social workers (Flentje et al., 2014). Oftentimes, various interventions used in conversion therapy have names that are similar to empirically supported interventions but the interventions themselves are virtually unrelated to said interventions (Shidlo & Gonsiorek, 2017). Shidlo and Gonsiorek (2017) explain that conversion therapy is based on flawed assumptions, namely that LGBTQ+ identities are “developmental disorders caused by poor relationships with parents, defective gender identity, social rejection, trauma, and sexual abuse” (p. 294). In addition, many of the techniques used in conversion therapy are sexist and focus primarily on men (Shidlo & Gonsiorek, 2017). Rix (2013) determined that the most common reasons for individuals to seek out conversion therapy were “religious beliefs, the desire to fit in socially, the wish to please family and friends, the fear of losing family and friends, and misinformation on what it means to be gay” (p. 12). Flentje (2007) reported that the most common reasons for terminating conversion therapy treatment were “acceptance of one’s sexual orientation and the realization that the individual participant could not change their sexual orientation” (p. 62).  One common subtype of conversion therapy was called aversion therapy, which was considered a form of behavior therapy aimed at ‘curing’ homosexuality. This was done by “associating electric shocks or nausea-inducing substances with homosexual   16 stimuli” (Clarke et al., 2010, p. 12). Another behavior-based subtype was called orgasmic reconditioning, which involved “associating heterosexual stimuli with masturbation” (Clarke et al., 2010, p. 12). Perhaps most severe were the mental health professionals who turned to surgical procedures in order to convert homosexuals into heterosexuals. Specifically, these providers surgically transplanted testicular cells from heterosexual men into homosexual men, castrated gay men, removed specific sections from the brains of gay men via cerebral ablation, and performed lobotomies (Silverstein, 2003).  Effects of Conversion Therapy Presently, there is no empirical evidence that conversion therapy can ‘cure’ homosexuality (Cramer et al., 2008; Davies & Neal, 1996). However, there is evidence that leaders of conversion therapy programs have a long history of inflicting “severe psychological damage” (Davies & Neal, 1996, p. 19) on their patients. Haldeman (1991) asserted that conversion therapy is unethical because it “reinforces the social stigma associated with homosexuality” (p. 8) and it persists despite evidence that sexual identity cannot be changed. Shidlo and Schroeder (2002) conducted a large study of 202 individuals who had experienced conversion therapy in order to assess their outcomes. A sizeable majority of participants indicated that their sexual identity had not changed to heterosexual, and they often spoke of the harms they experienced at the hands of clinicians who practiced conversion therapy. Gonsiorek (2004) asserts that attempts to change one’s sexual identity lack efficacy and introduce serious ethical concerns into a clinician’s work. Shidlo and Gonsiorek (2017) stated the significance of understanding that the effects of conversion therapy often include primary (LGBTQ+ individuals) and secondary (their loved ones) victims. The National Association of Social Workers (2007)   17 asserted that conversion therapy “cannot and will not change sexual orientation” (para. 5). Additionally, Tozer and McClanahan (1999) argued against the use of conversion therapy because an LGBTQ+ identity is not a pathological condition that requires treatment.  In 2009, the APA reviewed 83 studies that utilized conversion therapy and determined that claims of efficacy and safety are unsupported by research. The APA (2009) added that there is no scientific evidence that conversion therapy increases heterosexual attraction or decreases homosexual attraction. In fact, Shidlo and Gonsiorek (2017) asserted that the constructs utilized and supported by conversion therapy are contradicted by empirical studies. Largely as a result of the APA (2009) report and other similar research studies, 20 states and the District of Columbia have banned conversion therapy as of November 2021. An additional five states have partially banned conversion therapy for minors.  Meyer (2013) interviewed a former longtime participant in conversion therapy in order to gain a deeper understanding of what actually happens in conversion therapy and what the effects are on a personal level. For simplification purposes, this former participant will be referred to as Rob. When asked about constant messages that he heard in conversion therapy, Rob replied often hearing that being gay is a choice (Meyer, 2013). He also was told that he was a “criminal,” “immoral,” and “severely mentally ill” (Meyer, 2013, p. 39) individual. He also reported that he did not experience significant guilt about his sexual identity until he began conversion therapy (Meyer, 2013). After 3 years of conversion therapy, Rob struggled with depression, feelings of worthlessness, and severe suicidality (Meyer, 2013). Whenever he experienced setbacks, the consistent   18 reply was that he could become heterosexual if he tried “really, really hard” (Meyer, 2013, p. 40). As a result, he felt like a failure when he did not see progress over many years and sessions of conversion therapy. Rob also explained that he stayed in conversion therapy for so long because he strongly believed that his therapist was the only person in the world who had the ability to save him (Meyer, 2013).  In terms of ethical issues, APA (2009) determined that conversion therapy interventions often misrepresent empirical findings about LGBTQ+ mental health. Clinicians who conduct conversion therapy tend to engage in misinformation that leads to significant and long-lasting impacts on clients’ self-image (Beckstead & Morrow, 2004; Haldeman, 2002; Rix, 2013; Shidlo & Schroeder, 2002). Examples of this misinformation include statements that ignore the APA’s stance on LGBTQ+ individuals, statements that LGBTQ+ identities are psychological disorders, and statements that LGBTQ+ lives and relationships are chronically unhappy (Shidlo & Schroeder, 2002). Clinicians utilizing conversion therapy also fail to follow the American Psychological Association (2012)’s guidelines for psychological practice with lesbian, gay, and bisexual clients because these guidelines prohibit discrimination, misrepresentation of empirical data, and require informed consent that would include a statement on the lack of empirical support for conversion therapy. Jenkins and Johnston (2004) maintained that clinicians who practice conversion therapy breach ethical principles by promising they can change their clients’ sexual identities and by portraying all LGBTQ+ individuals as miserable and hopeless people. Beckstead and Morrow (2004) and Shidlo and Schroeder (2002) conducted studies that assessed the perceived negative impact of undergoing conversion therapy.   19 They found that participants reported a decrease in self-esteem and authenticity, an increase in internalized homophobia, an increase in negative views on LGBTQ+ individuals, and increases in depression, hopelessness, shame, anger, social withdrawal, and suicidality (Beckstead & Morrow, 2004; Shidlo & Schroeder, 2002). Participants also demonstrated increased substance use and “high-risk sexual behaviors” (APA, 2009, p. 50). Beckstead and Morrow (2004) and Shidlo and Schroeder (2002) reported that participants experienced a loss of religious identity and beliefs that they had wasted their time and resources pursuing conversion therapy. One primary finding in these studies was that participants experienced significant disruption in their relationships with others. Participants reported hostility toward their parents, anger toward their clinicians, loss of LGBTQ+ friends, struggles with emotional intimacy in romantic relationships, and feelings of shame when they engaged in same-sex sexual behaviors (Beckstead & Morrow, 2004; Drescher, 2006; Haldeman, 2001; Shidlo & Schroeder, 2002).  In 2011, Maccio conducted a cross-sectional research study with 37 individuals who had participated in conversion therapy. There was no statistically significant difference between the sexual orientation of participants before and after conversion therapy experiences (Maccio, 2011). Any noted changes in sexual identity through conversion therapy were slight, such as identifying as bisexual at the outset of treatment and identifying as gay at the end of treatment (Maccio, 2011). Maccio (2011) also determined that participants’ sexual behaviors, sexual feelings, and sexual thoughts did not change from pre- to post-conversion therapy. In 2006, Johnston and Jenkins surveyed 14 gay men who had undergone extensive conversion therapy. Many participants shared feelings of despair, fear, and   20 loneliness when they realized they were attracted to people of their own gender identity (Johnston & Jenkins, 2006). In response to these feelings, participants prayed to be changed, repressed their feelings, and finally turned to conversion therapy whenever those attempts failed (Johnston & Jenkins, 2006). They were clearly experiencing a significant amount of conflict between acknowledging their sexual identity and realizing that their identity was not compatible with their religious affiliations (Johnson & Jenkins, 2006). Once they began conversion therapy, common messages they received were that they were “sinful, sick, and weak” (Johnston & Jenkins, 2006, p. 69) and that they were not improving due to a “lack of effort, inherent depravity, or demonic possession.” Over time, several participants recounted believing that God hated them because they were not changing despite their best efforts (Johnston & Jenkins, 2006). Rather than giving them hope for what life might look like if they embraced a sexual minority identity, their therapists “portrayed gay men and lesbians as miserable people with no hope of finding happiness” (Johnston & Jenkins, 2006, p. 71). Overall, none of the 14 participants experienced significant or long-lasting change in their sexual identity (Johnston & Jenkins, 2006).  Over the past 20 years, there are many empirical studies that have proven the negative effects of conversion therapy. These effects include feelings of depression, guilt, hopelessness, poor self-image, suicidal ideation, suicide attempts, suicide planning, self-hatred, sexual dysfunction, violence, shame, loss of familial and social support, loss of faith, intimacy avoidance, and confusion about one’s sexual identity (APA, 2009; Beckstead & Morrow, 2004; Blosnich et al., 2020; Flentje, 2007; Flentje et al., 2014; Haldeman, 2001; Haldeman, 2002; Meyer, 2015; Przeworski et al., 2020; Rix, 2013;   21 Ryan et al., 2020; Shidlo & Schroeder, 2002). Shidlo and Gonsiorek (2017) concluded that most of these negative effects were caused by the following four factors: being told that their sexual identity is a mental disorder, being told that they can change their sexual identity if they are motivated enough, blaming clients whenever conversion therapy fails to work, and leading clients to have feelings of contempt towards themselves and towards other LGBTQ+ individuals. Despite the numerous negative impacts that have been reported regarding conversion therapy, it is not surprising that many GSM individuals seek to change their sexual identity because of the ways that society devalues non-heterosexual individuals and continues to demonstrate institutional homophobia in many aspects of our lives (Haldeman, 1994).  Methodological Analysis of Conversion Therapy Research Studies  Shidlo and Gonsiorek (2017) noted that a significant majority of published studies on conversion therapy show a clear “abhorrence toward LGB persons, relationships, and communities” (p. 295). One example of this abhorrence is found in a study conducted by Nicolosi (1993): “Homosexual relationships are so characteristically volatile because the homosexual hates what he loves” (p. 152). Satinover (1996) went so far as to characterize the “battle over homosexuality” as the “defining moment of our society” (p. 250). Haldeman (2002) asserted that common methodological concerns of conversion therapy studies were sampling bias, heavy reliance on testimonials, and response bias. In addition to methodological flaws, many research studies that supported the use of conversion therapy focused on three questions: “Are homosexuals sick?” “How can homosexuality be diagnosed?” and “What causes homosexuality?” (Clarke et al., 2010, p. 12).    22  In 2003, Spitzer published research that he believed supported claims that homosexual individuals could become heterosexual through conversion therapy. Once this research was published, many ex-gay organizations and practitioners of conversion therapy used these results to support their views (Grace, 2008). Spitzer (2003) also argued against the harms of conversion therapy by declaring that conversion therapy was beneficial to the participants in his study. However, many psychologists found that Spitzer’s research findings were weak after conducting several methodological reviews (Grace, 2008). Several critiques of Spitzer’s research were published, including the fact that Spitzer used selection bias of a narrowly stratified population (Grace, 2008). Spitzer also exclusively relied on self-reporting to support his claims of effectiveness, which is problematic considering the pressure for participants to report that they had changed and had become more socially and religiously desirable individuals as a result of treatment (Grace, 2008). In addition, Spitzer’s study used a retrospective design that asked participants to recall events from an average of 12 years prior (Grace, 2008). Perhaps most notably, Spitzer did not establish a cause-and-effect relationship, “so he cannot claim that reported changes in sexual orientation were due to prayer as suggested by some survey respondents” (Grace, 2008, p. 571). In a surprising shift, Spitzer released an apology about the flaws in his 2003 study, stating that he made “unproven claims of efficacy” (Hancock et al., 2012, p. 500) of conversion therapy and that he apologized to anyone who pursued conversion therapy as a result of his supposed proof that conversion therapy was effective.   As part of the APA’s Task Force on Appropriate Therapeutic Responses to Sexual Orientation report in 2009, methodological concerns in conversion therapy research   23 studies were discussed in depth. One primary concern was that the research “does not provide a sound basis for making compelling causal claims” (APA, 2009, p. 28). More specifically, a lack of internal validity in conversion therapy studies makes it difficult to state that changes in people’s “attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors are a function of the particular interventions to which they were exposed” (APA, 2009, p. 28). Next, the APA reported that high sample attrition of up to 74% significantly lowered the overall sample sizes of conversion therapy studies (APA, 2009). In recent research on conversion therapy, a high reliance on self-reporting and measures with questionable psychometric properties including validity and reliability have been noted (APA, 2009). Another important consideration when evaluating the results of research studies is if the sample is representative of the group of people you are basing your findings on. The APA (2009) found that the majority of participants in most conversion therapy studies were white males over the age of 18. In studies across the history of conversion therapy research, there is a lack of racial diversity and there are little to no studies that have been conducted on children and adolescents (APA, 2009).  Next, the APA (2009) assessed the outcomes of conversion therapy studies. They found that none of the experimental studies they analyzed had compared outcomes to a control group (APA, 2009). When short-term reductions in same-sex behaviors were reported, they were often for people who described an attraction to men and women at the outset of treatment (APA, 2009). In the only randomized control group study that was found, the intervention did not affect same-sex sexual behavior (APA, 2009). Generally, the results from research studies on conversion therapy do not suggest that conversion therapy can increase sexual behavior with the other sex (APA, 2009). It was also   24 determined that studies that claimed an increase in participants’ overall quality of life had no basis for those claims because they did not adequately track mental health outcomes after the conclusion of treatment (APA, 2009).  The Ex-Gay Movement The ex-gay movement, or peer-based conversion therapy, peaked in the 1990s. During the 1990s, Exodus International had 120 local organizations in the United States and Canada and an additional 150 in other countries (Shidlo & Gonsiorek, 2017). Davies and Neal (1996) explained that individuals within the ‘ex-gay movement’ recruit vulnerable LGBTQ+ individuals by offering to ‘cure’ their sexual identity. This is often done by targeting individuals who strongly identify with their religious identity and who want to change their sexual identity as a direct result of their religiosity. Essentially, some Christians at the individual and institutional level have a concerning history of maximizing one’s psychological distress related to their sexual identity. Once this distress is elevated, they proceed to suggest that conversion therapy is the only viable solution to this distress (Gonsiorek, 2004). “At their core, conversion therapies seek to legitimize the use of psychological techniques and behavioral science to enforce compliance with religious orthodoxy” (Gonsiorek, 2004, p. 755). Gonsiorek (2004) adds that religious beliefs strongly influence negative beliefs about one’s LGBTQ+ identity and strongly influence one’s decision to seek out conversion therapy.  Grace (2008) conducted an in-depth study on the Christian ex-gay movement, what was used to support the movement’s claims of efficacy, and the impact of this movement on ex-gay individuals and those who participated in ex-gay facilitated conversion therapy. One of the foremost ex-gay institutions was Exodus International. In   25 fact, it was the oldest and largest institution that focused on religion and homosexuality. Founded in 1976, it became infamous for inflicting pain on thousands of individuals and for promoting sexual identity change efforts that traumatized and stigmatized these individuals and their families (Alessi, 2013). Exodus International’s mission statement stated the following: “Exodus is an international Christian effort to reach homosexuals and lesbians. Exodus upholds God’s standard of righteousness and holiness, which declares that homosexuality is sin and affirms His love and redemptive power to recreate the individual” (Grace, 2008). During the 1980s, Exodus International used the AIDS epidemic to increase interest in their mission of redemption for homosexuals. They played on the gay community’s fears about contracting AIDS, dying, and going to hell in order to bring more people to their mission (Grace, 2008). Exodus International regularly took Old Testament biblical scripture out of context and manipulated it to support their programs on a nationwide scale (Grace, 2008). In the mid-1990s, Exodus International took out full-page ads in major U.S. newspapers like The Washington Post and The New York Times in order to further spread the word of their “cure” for homosexuality. At the same time, conservative politicians and religious groups conducted major media campaigns in order to limit the civil rights of LGBTQ+ individuals and to preach the message that homosexuality is a choice that can be changed (Grace, 2008).  In 2001, Ford shared his experiences as a recipient of conversion therapy and later his reactions to these experiences as he became a mental health clinician and heard many clients report similar stories. He first shares that he was eager to attempt ex-gay therapy because his religion offered love when he was feeling his most vulnerable and isolated (Ford, 2001). This type of treatment was also seen as attractive because it was a place   26 where he could “acknowledge his sexual and affectional feelings without fear of rejection” (Ford, 2001, p. 71), and his participation was viewed as an obedience to God. At first, the love he experienced in the ex-gay ministry was “liberating” (Ford, 2001, p. 71), though he soon realized that love was purely conditional. A constant message he received was that accepting himself as a homosexual would keep him from heaven, which was a significant fear due to his religious beliefs and the importance he placed on them (Ford, 2001). As the honeymoon phase ends, failures are not tolerated and reporting of such failures often leads to severe chastisement (Ford, 2001). The treatment is never seen as the failure during these experiences. Rather, the person’s “relationship with God” (Ford, 2001, p. 73) is seen as the reason why their sexual identity is not changing. Ford (2001) reported a fear of abandonment so severe that he did not feel safe telling his therapist the truth and consistently viewed suicide as a “viable option” (p. 74). He added that “the thought of living my life as a gay man and going to hell seemed much worse than taking my own life while I was still in grace” (Ford, 2001, p. 79). Another trend was that many ex-gay therapists were known to have sexual relations with program participants and were often removed from their posts as a result (Ford, 2001). After several years of therapy with gay affirming therapy, Ford (2001) was able to experience happiness and security in his identity as a gay man.  When looking at the programs that made up Exodus International, it is clear that they focused on the rejection and sadness that gay men struggled with and provided them with an apparent solution (Grace, 2008). Once they entered the program, participants were subject to a deleterious process of blaming themselves and others for their sexual identities. Participants were told that they could not be fulfilled, were sinners who were   27 “sexually broken”, weak, and confused individuals who became gay because they had “absentee, uncaring, or otherwise abusive parents” (Grace, 2008, p. 551). They were also told that people choose homosexuality after experiences with incest and/or molestation (Grace, 2008). If it seems surprising that so many people turned to Exodus International given this information, consider that it often seemed like the only possible solution for LGBTQ+ people who struggled with familial rejection and religious condemnation (Haldeman, 2001). When the organization closed their doors in 2012, the president of Exodus International apologized for the damage that was done to the many LGB individuals who sought out their services.  Institutionalized & Internalized Homophobia Institutionalized Homophobia Institutionalized homophobia essentially translates to institutions and systems assuming that everyone is heterosexual and cisgender (Davies & Neal, 1996). Consider times in your own life when you may have noticed that people assumed that you have an opposite sex partner rather than asking before the fact. Generally, society does not consider the fact that there are many LGBTQ+ people in the world and that this ignorance adds to feelings of exclusion by anyone who is not heterosexual and cisgender.  One classic example of institutionalized homophobia being mentioned in academic literature is Tinney’s (1983) discussion of several different ways that society oppresses LGB people (transgender individuals are not mentioned in this article, unfortunately). One example mentioned is society’s attempt to keep large numbers of LGBTQ+ people from interacting with each other outside of LGBTQ+ bars and clubs. In many areas, there are zero LGBTQ+ community centers and zero places for LGBTQ+   28 minors to meet with each other, especially outside of major cities. Boswell (1980) cited numerous examples of history being revised to ignore positive mentions of LGBTQ+ culture and contributions made by LGBTQ+ people. This was done by simple deletion, censorship, and even changing of gender identities (Boswell, 1980). Another example is that the general population tends to minimize the existence and strength of LGBTQ+ people across the world. Additionally, there is often a “fear of over-visibility” (Tinney, 1983, p. 45) where people feel uncomfortable discussing non-heterosexual relationships and often complain if LGBTQ+ individuals share about their experiences in public. Finally, Tinney (1983) asserts that society assigns negative symbolism to people who deviate from the societal norm of identifying as heterosexual and cisgender. LGBTQ+ people are stereotyped as being shallow, promiscuous, drug-loving, and eager to “recruit” unsuspecting children and adolescents to join them.  Even today, schools often refuse to teach students about LGBTQ+ identities for fear of retribution by parents, government agencies, and educational institutions. When positive examples of LGBTQ+ identities are left out of schools, young people are being indirectly taught that identifying as such is unnatural, unhealthy, and uncommon (Davies & Neal, 1996). This lack of education also serves to further support the homophobia that still pervades a significant sector of society.  Whenever LGBTQ+ characters are introduced in films, television shows, and miniseries, they are still often depicted as stereotypical people who are loud, dramatic, simple-minded, and oversexualized. LGBTQ+ media representation is crucial to communicating the fact that being LGBTQ+ is normal, healthy, and relatively common to a large audience. Even “classic” LGB television shows such as Will & Grace (Mutchnick   29 et al., 1998-2006), Queer as Folk (Jonas et al., 2000-2005), and The L Word (Chaiken et al., 2004-2009) tended to depict mainly white, cisgender characters.  Institutionalized homophobia even permeates the world of mental health. For example, there is still a tendency for clinicians to assume that LGBTQ+ clients are in therapy for issues related to their sexual and/or gender identities. While this may certainly be the case, it is not true 100% of the time.  Internalized Homophobia While institutionalized homophobia exists at the institutional and societal level, internalized homophobia primarily exists at the individual level. As a result, experiences with internalized homophobia/biphobia/transphobia vary widely across clients. Internalized homophobia indicates the experience that LGBTQ+ individuals have when they take the hate and prejudice they experience and observe and turn it inwardly on their own sexual and gender identities. Internalized homophobia can lead to a dissatisfaction in one’s sexual and/or gender identity, hatred of oneself in general, and even self-destructive behaviors. In addition, internalized homophobia is associated with depression, anxiety, romantic relationship issues, social isolation, and even suicide (Alderson, 2013; Hill, 2009). Similarly, Love et al. (2014) found that internalized homophobia was related to issues with self-esteem, social support, intimacy, and overall emotional distress. These experiences often evolve into LGBTQ+ people feeling unhappy with their identity and wishing they were heterosexual and cisgender instead. Hansbury and Bennett (2014) asserted that all gay, bisexual, and transgender people “have internalized homo/bi/transphobia” as a result of growing up in a “homophobic society that either   30 tends to promote prejudicial myths about gay, bisexual, and transgender people or negates their existence in general” (p. 204). LGBTQ+ Affirming Therapy Introduction to LGBTQ+ Affirming Therapy Unlike other types of psychotherapy, LGBTQ+ affirmative therapy is not its own separate system of therapy (Johnson, 2012). Instead, it involves a specialized knowledge that uses “traditional psychotherapeutic methods but proceeds from a non-traditional perspective” (Maylon, 1982, p. 69). As a result, affirming therapy can be used in conjunction with a traditional system, such as Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). LGBTQ+ affirming therapy considers homophobia, rather than homosexuality, as a significant concern to address in therapy (Benson, 2013; Maylon, 1982). Additionally, it is important that LGBTQ+ affirming clinicians see an LGBTQ+ identity as equal to a heterosexual and cisgender identity (Alderson, 2013; Corturillo et al., 2016). Crisp and McCave (2007) summarized the goals of an LGBTQ+ affirming clinician as someone who “celebrates, advocates, and validates the identities” (p. 405) of LGBTQ+ clients.   History Historically, one of the first affirmative views of homosexuality came from the publication of Sexual Behavior in the Human Male by Kinsey, Pomeroy, and Martin in 1948 and Sexual Behavior in the Human Female by Kinsey, Pomeroy, Martin, and Gebhard in 1953. These studies demonstrated that having a minority sexual identity was more common than was previously believed and suggested that such identities were normal identities (APA, 2009). In 1957, Hooker reported that homosexual men were just as well-adjusted to everyday life as heterosexual men. Three years later in 1960, Armon replicated these results with lesbian women. In the 1970s, several research studies compared the personality of homosexual and heterosexual individuals using personality   34 measures like Cattell’s Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire, the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory, and the Eysenck Personality Inventory (APA, 2009). These researchers found that gay men and lesbian women were similar to heterosexual men and women in overall functioning and adjustment (APA, 2009). Just as important, research studies done from the 1960s-1990s consistently demonstrated that family dynamics and traumatic experiences did not impact the development of one’s sexual identity, which challenged the psychopathological view of homosexuality (APA, 2009).  Core Concepts of LGBTQ+ Affirming Therapy Moradi and Budge (2018) view LGBTQ+ affirming therapy as encompassing four overarching points of emphasis (with examples in parentheses): working against anti-LGBTQ+ therapist beliefs by emphasizing LGBTQ+ affirmative beliefs (communicating clinician beliefs that LGBTQ+ individuals are equal to cisgender and heterosexual individuals), gathering information regarding the experiences and diversity of LGBTQ+ individuals (engaging in meaningful discussion about diversity within LGBTQ+ communities), integrating said information into therapeutic conceptualization and interventions (intentionally including how cultural context impacts LGBTQ+ clients and their presenting concerns), and “engaging in and affirming challenges to power inequities” (p. 2030) (discussing said inequities with clients and communicating understanding of this reality with clients).  Davies and Neal (1996) contend that respect is a “core condition” (p. 26) of affirming therapy, and that there are four specific types of respect within that condition: respect for the client’s sexual identity, respect for personal integrity, respect for lifestyle and culture, and respectful attitudes and beliefs. Respect for the client’s sexual identity   35 means that the clinician accepts that a non-heterosexual identity is just as healthy and is equal to a heterosexual identity (Davies & Neal, 1996). Respect for personal integrity means that the therapeutic relationship is collaborative in nature and that the clinician acts as a “companion in the client’s journey, rather than the tour guide” (p. 26). In terms of respect for lifestyle and culture, clinicians are tasked with learning about the diversity of cultural identities that exist within the LGBTQ+ community. It is essential to keep in mind that it is not the client’s job to teach a clinician about the LGBTQ+ community in general terms (Davies & Neal, 1996). Finally, respectful attitudes and beliefs translates to a crucial duty of clinicians to fully understand their own values and attitudes regarding sexual and gender identity prior to working with LGBTQ+ clients (Davies & Neal, 1996). In terms of beliefs, there are several that would make it impossible for a clinician to apply LGBTQ+ affirming therapy to their clients, including beliefs that a non-heterosexual identity is sinful, unnatural, a perversion, inferior to a heterosexual identity, that relationships can only be sexual, that LGBTQ+ parents are not equal to heterosexual parents, and that bisexual individuals can decide to be either heterosexual or homosexual (Davies & Neal, 1996). Hinrichs and Donaldson (2017) assert that a critical condition of affirming therapy is the development of a trusting therapeutic relationship that features active listening, validation, and an openness to explore all issues related to sexual and gender identities. At times, affirmative therapy can be utilized in order to address a client’s insecurities and self-criticism that have been exacerbated by society’s views on LGBTQ+ individuals (Hinrichs & Donaldson, 2017). Hinrichs and Donaldson (2017) added that clients often do most of the therapeutic work themselves once an affirmative and   36 nonjudgmental environment has been established within the context of therapy. Appleby and Anastas (1998) suggest that there are six core principles of LGBTQ+ affirming therapy: Not assuming that clients are heterosexual; believing that homophobia and not an LGBTQ+ identity is the problem; believing that having an LGBTQ+ identity is a positive outcome of therapy; assisting clients in reducing experiences of internalized homophobia; being educated about the coming out process; and addressing one’s own biases related to homophobia and heterosexism. In 2009, the American Psychological Association’s Task Force on Appropriate Therapeutic Responses to Sexual Orientation released a 140-page report detailing LGBTQ+ affirming therapy, evidence-based practice when working with GSM clients, a history of conversion therapy, and a review of conversion therapy effects. At the heart of LGBTQ+ affirming therapy are the beliefs that LGBTQ+ identities are stigmatized and can have many negative effects across the life span; LGBTQ+ sexual and gender identities are normal variants of human sexuality; and LGBTQ+ individuals can enjoy “satisfying lives and form stable, committed relationships and families that are equivalent to heterosexuals’ relationships and families in essential respects” (APA, 2009, p. 14). The American Psychological Association (2009) advocated the use of a person-centered approach that emphasizes unconditional positive regard, empathy, openness to client perspectives, and “encouragement of the client’s positive self-concept” (p. 55). Affirmative approaches view one’s sexual and gender identities as being a significant aspect of one’s personality and sense of self (APA, 2009).     37 Common Topics When Working with LGBTQ+ Clients Long (1996) interviewed LGBTQ+ clients and asked them what they would like their prospective therapist to know. Their responses centered around four major themes: “awareness of invisibility in society; coming out as a continual process; social and political LGBT history; and awareness of the effects of homo/transphobia, including the impact of violence” (p. 382). In addition, common topics that arise when working with GSM clients include discrimination, prejudice, rejection, relationship adjustments with friends and family, and difficulty working in inclusive environments (Butler, 2010).  Another common concern that often arises when working with LGBTQ+ individuals is a lengthy history of experiencing rejection. This rejection may come from the world at large, friends, family, and other loved ones as a result of them identifying as non-heterosexual and/or non-cisgender (Nel et al., 2007). Perhaps even more damaging is the fact that this rejection often extends to one’s self-rejection as a result of these experiences (Nel et al., 2007). This self-rejection is not unlike the concerns regarding internalized homophobia that are discussed in prior sections of the current project. Interventions In terms of techniques, Benson (2013) found that simply adopting and communicating an affirmative stance towards a client’s various identities was powerful for a significant number of transgender clients. Regarding LGBTQ+ affirming interventions, the most effective ones focus on “helping the individual develop self-love and a respect for others who” (Alderson, 2013, p. 54) identify as LGBTQ+. If you prefer to use a Cognitive Behavioral Therapy approach, you may ask your clients, “What proof do you have that you are less than heterosexual people because you define as gay?”   38 (Alderson, 2013, p. 54). Participants in a qualitative study done by Rostosky et al. (2008) shared that they coped with their sexual identity and racial identity stressors by “seeking support, meaning making, using humor, using active problem solving, and avoidant behaviors” (p.71). McKinney et al. (2020) recommend the following interventions: acceptance practices to validate clients within invalidating environments, challenging heteronormative societal messages through advocacy, utilizing thought logs for analyzing and modifying negative self-talk, and “interpersonal training to build positive supports and mitigate negative social forces” (p. 184). Furthermore, Love et al. (2014) determined that the use of empathy significantly predicted the overall use of LGBTQ+ affirming therapy.  Crisp and McCave (2007) and Hill (2009) recommend a strengths-based approach when utilizing LGBTQ+ affirming therapy that emphasizes psychological health rather than pathology, addresses clients’ skills in self-determination, and builds on their existing strengths. In addition, Hill (2009) identified the goal of affirming therapy as assisting clients in “developing enough resistance to internalized oppression, enough clarity about sexual orientation and identity, and enough skill at making decisions about disclosure so that energy is freed for other life goals” (p. 354). Love et al. (2014) asserts that affirming therapy involves “celebrating and advocating the validity of” (p. 86) LGBTQ+ individuals and working against the messages they have received across their lives that promote homophobia, heterosexism, and internalized homophobia.  Zapor and Stuart (2016) recommend utilizing an affirmative CBT approach, especially when depression is a primary presenting concern because it “closely examines the environmental and social context of the client’s life, which may be colored by   39 heterosexism and discrimination” (p. 146). Additionally, affirmative CBT encourages clients to practice active problem solving while keeping in mind that one’s sexual identity and/or gender identity may have a major or minor impact on their presenting concerns (Zapor & Stuart, 2016). Pachankis (2009) promoted using affirmative CBT to promote authenticity through assertiveness training. Specifically, assertiveness training “encourages individuals to identify their individual rights…in any given situation and to act in accordance with those rights in a way that promotes self-respect” (Pachankis, 2009, p. 33). Job and Williams (2020) provided research data that supports the use of Positive Psychology when working with GSM clients. Interventions with the highest effect sizes included emphasis on love, humor, spirituality, self-compassion, gratitude, and optimism (Job & Williams, 2020). When outcomes were assessed, building self-compassion in clients was found to reduce psychological distress and increase resiliency in the face of minority stress (Job & Williams, 2020). Optimism was also found to be a key ingredient in successful Positive Psychology interventions with GSM clients, especially in reducing distress related to anticipated stigma (Job & Williams, 2020). In addition, establishment and/or maintenance of social support was found to improve health outcomes and mitigate the negative effects of minority stress (Job & Williams, 2020). A unique intervention that was supported by research is the use of humor interventions in order to reduce depression, increase happiness, and introduce a new positive coping skill (Job & Williams, 2020). In fact, 70% of participants indicated that humor interventions were helpful in dealing with homophobia and heterosexism (Job & Williams, 2020).    40 Strengths-based interventions are a crucial evidence-based practice that have proven to be effective at improving client wellness and reducing psychological symptoms (Smalley et al., 2018). Westcott (2020) posited that LGBTQ+ individuals have unique strengths that “promote psychological well-being in the LGBT community” (p. 8), such as: resilience, creativity, bravery, authenticity, love, and stress-related growth. When considering character strengths, integrity, love, gratitude, creativity, and fairness have been associated with LGBTQ+ clients (Westcott, 2020). Westcott (2020) recommended interventions that focus on helping LGBTQ+ clients develop positive identities, resources, and strengths in order to improve psychological functioning, reduce the impact of minority stress, and increase LGBTQ+ community connectedness. When conducting strengths-based work, it is important to begin with client-identified strengths and then assess for further strengths if necessary.  Smalley et al. (2018) researched evidence-based interventions for GSM individuals at the individual and interpersonal levels. In terms of individual-level interventions, they reported that an expressive writing intervention involving a 20-minute writing exercise three times per week for two weeks was found to reduce perceived stress (Smalley et al., 2018). Another expressive writing intervention resulted in increased openness about sexual identity, decreased mental health symptomatology, and decreased internalized heterosexism three months after the intervention concluded (Smalley et al., 2018). At the interpersonal level, a family therapy focused on attachment for suicidal GSM adolescents was found to reduce depressive symptoms, suicidal ideation, and avoidance (Smalley et al., 2018).     41 LGBTQ+ Affirming Group Therapy Nel et al. LGBTQ+ Affirming Therapy for Children & Adolescents Austin and Craig (2015) asserted that LGBTQ+ affirming therapy for children and adolescents should focus on empowerment rather than pathologization, “supporting   42 self-determination; considering presenting problems within a context of homophobia, transphobia, and discrimination” (p. 569), and encourage clients to challenge the heteronormativity, homophobia, and transphobia that they encounter. In addition, they emphasized identifying and establishing affirmative support systems (Austin & Craig, 2015). Overall, they saw the goal of affirming therapy as helping youth to “develop positive sexual and gender identities in large part by empowering them to cope effectively with identity based stigma and discrimination” (p. 569).
