Fluidity in Sexual and Gender Identity If one is considering the use of LGBTQ+ affirming therapy, it is important to keep in mind that binary models of sexual identity severely limit our awareness of the experiences of people who identify as bisexual, pansexual, asexual, fluid, polysexual, queer, and many more (Clarke et al., 2010). When working with clients who identify as queer, it is important to know that they may be opposed to aligning themselves with a definitive sexual and/or gender identity (Clarke et al., 2010). This consideration can provide a crucial opportunity for clinicians to discuss how society and culture impact   43 how LGBTQ+ clients see themselves as individuals and as people who are part of the larger society (Clarke et al., 2010).  Discussing Conversion Therapy in the Context of LGBTQ+ Affirming Therapy Given the fact that thousands of individuals have experiences with conversion therapy, it is likely that clinicians would work with LGBTQ+ clients who have experienced conversion therapy. In these instances, Shidlo and Gonsiorek (2017) recommend educating clients on the following: identifying as LGBTQ+ is healthy and normal, there is no basis for claims that LGBTQ+ couples are psychologically dysfunctional, LGBTQ+ couples’ parenting abilities are the same as heterosexual individuals, and the “effectiveness of (conversion therapy) is unsubstantiated and their theories are erroneous” (p. 303). Clinicians should also be aware of the potential for such clients to struggle with tension between their sexual identity, religious identity, and other identities that are preventing LGBTQ+ clients from experiencing an integrated and cohesive identity (Shidlo & Gonsiorek, 2017).  Working with Internalized Homophobia As a clinician, it is important to bring internalized homophobia to the awareness of your LGBTQ+ clients (if indicated) and to discuss the messages that society gives us all about sexual and gender identities. Ideally, this can lead to conversations about the impact of those messages on your client’s feelings about themselves and about other people who share similar identities. It is not uncommon for issues of internalized homophobia to be part of an LGBTQ+ client’s presenting concerns and reasons for seeking therapy, but clinicians must be careful not to assume that this is always the case.    44  When working with internalized homophobia in therapy, clinicians may want to engage in cognitive restructuring in order to create a positive view of one’s sexual and/or gender identity. When discussing stereotypes of the LGBTQ+ community, it is important to include discussion about diversity and intersectionality within the community (Davies & Neal, 1996). Another solution could be to discuss the possibility of self-disclosure or ‘coming out’, but only when it is safe, and the client feels comfortable doing so. At times, establishing or maintaining an LGBTQ+ support system can also serve to reduce one’s feelings of internalized homophobia (Davies & Neal, 1996). Davies and Neal (1996) recommend working on internalized homophobia and more adaptive coping strategies when dealing with societal homophobia rather than helping clients find a ‘cure’ for their LGBTQ+ identity.  Clinician Self-Disclosure If an LGBTQ+ clinician is working with LGBTQ+ clients, an inner conflict may arise over whether or not they should disclose their own sexual or gender identity to their clients. When considering this, it is important to understand the purpose of such self-disclosure. Hanbury and Bennett (2014) advocate for therapist self-disclosure if the purpose is to “provide a model and to detoxify the client’s shame” (p. 209). Self-disclosure could also be appropriate if the clinician intends to communicate a deeper level of empathy that non-LGBTQ+ clinicians cannot. Others see such self-disclosure not as a possibility but as an inevitability (Cole & Drescher, 2006). Clinician self-disclosure can also serve to “make therapy a more readily viable choice for those who have felt shunned and pathologized by those who purported to offer them help” (Cole & Drescher,   45 2006, p. 3). Harrison (2000) also expressed support for clinician self-disclosure, especially as a way to provide a “positive role model” (p. 39).  Therapeutic Alliance Bettergarcia and Israel (2018) affirmed that the therapeutic relationship is of critical concern when working with transgender clients. Their research results indicated that the therapeutic relationship can be strengthened when an affirming approach is utilized (Bettergarcia & Israel, 2018). Furthermore, seeing a clinician as affirming made trans clients more likely to view their clinicians as trustworthy, an expert in their field, and likeable (Bettergarcia & Israel, 2018). Bettergarcia and Israel (2018) demonstrated that the strongest predictor of overall psychological adjustment, positive affect, self-esteem, and optimism was the therapeutic relationship. Burckell and Goldfried (2006) also communicated support for the importance of “establishing and maintaining a strong therapeutic alliance” (p. 45). Impact of Using LGBTQ+ Affirming Therapy Use of affirming therapy has been found to have a substantial impact on the lives of LGBTQ+ individuals. Smalley et al. (2018) found that 80% of individuals who received affirming care reported improvement in gender dysphoria, 78% improved in psychological symptom presentation, and 80% improved in overall well-being. Affirmative therapy was found to increase active coping skills during times of increased distress and the use of cognitive strategies were found to reduce self-stigma and reduce negative self-beliefs (APA, 2009). Research has indicated that affirmative CBT can result in significantly decreased depression, anxiety, and overall psychological distress compared to baseline functioning (Zapor & Stuart, 2016).   46 Importance of Clinician Training in LGBTQ+ Affirming Therapy Davies and Neal (1996) suggest that clinician trainers educate students about LGBTQ+ issues in order to minimize any pressure on clients who may feel compelled to educate clinicians within the therapeutic context. Trainers are also encouraged to teach students about the development of sexual and gender identity, the coming out process, and LGBTQ+ issues across the lifespan. Additionally, it is important to avoid homophobia within the areas of supervision and consultation. In these instances, it is critical for supervisors, supervisees, and consultants to remain vigilant for signs of homophobia and to address them as they arise in an appropriate but open manner (Davies & Neal, 1996).  McGeorge et al. (2018) highlighted the importance of training in working with LGBTQ+ clients because LGBTQ+ individuals seek therapy services at higher rates than people who identify as heterosexual. If LGBTQ+ clients do not feel their clinicians are not educated in the nuances of working with this population, rapport may be difficult to establish and progress may be hindered (McGeorge et al., 2018). Additionally, the mental health concerns that LGBTQ+ people experience as a result of living in a heterosexist society make clinician training essential in order to provide the support they deserve (McGeorge et al., 2018).  Despite the importance of LGBTQ+-focused clinical training, Chazin and Klugman (2014) reported that a significant number of clinicians feel they have limited knowledge in working with LGBTQ+ clients. Bettergarcia and Israel (2018) affirmed that educating clinicians about supportive and affirmative therapy is “key to increasing positive experiences, decreasing negative experiences, and building trust with   47 transgender communities” (p. 429). Corturillo et al. (2016) stressed the importance of faculty members attaining knowledge about the negative impact that living in a heterosexist world has on the experiences of LGBTQ+ clients. In their quest to assess the education of faculty members regarding working with LGBTQ+ clients, Corturillo et al. (2016) found that many faculty members reported receiving very little LGBTQ+ affirmative training. Specifically, 44.6% of respondents reported that they had received this type of training during their graduate training. Even when faculty members had received such training, they reported that most of such courses were “non-clinical courses, such as human development, family science, and human sexuality” (Corturillo et al., 2016, p. 68). As a result, it is crucial that faculty members receive clinically based training that specifically focuses on clinical experiences with LGBTQ+ clients. Furthermore, Corturillo et al. (2016) recommend an approach to training that includes LGBTQ+ considerations in each aspect of one’s educational experience, particularly in graduate school training.  Further stating the importance of faculty member training, McGeorge et al. (2018) found that faculty members’ level of LGBTQ+ clinical training predicted the degree to which they incorporated LGBTQ+-focused training in their own courses. When considering course content, McGeorge et al. (2018) recommend teaching students about “the sociopolitical constructs that negatively influence the lives of LGB individuals and relationships, such as sexual minority prejudice, gay-related stress, internalized homophobia, heterosexism, heterosexual privilege, and heteronormativity” (p. 4). Constantine (2001) determined that multicultural training and the presence of empathy significantly predicted a clinician’s ability to successfully implement LGBTQ+ affirming   48 therapy. Alessi et al. (2016) found that more LGBTQ+ competency training hours were associated with “more affirmative attitudes, higher levels of affirmative counseling self-efficacy, and more positive beliefs” (p. 453).  Carlson et al. (2013) created the Affirmative Training Inventory (ATI) in order to determine how much training student clinicians receive in working with LGBTQ+ clients. They decided to assess the validity and factorial structure of the ATI in order to determine how well the ATI measures LGBTQ+ training (Carlson et al., 2013). Carlson et al. (2013) determined that the ATI is a valid measure of LGBTQ+ affirmative training. This outcome suggests that preparing students to work with LGBTQ+ clients includes course-based training, supervision, and an “overall LGBTQ+ affirmative environment in the training program” (Carlson et al., 2013, p. 218). As a result, the emphasis should be on how all faculty members view working with LGBTQ+ clients because of the impact that this can have on a program’s overall environment. Carlson et al. (2013) also determined that the more students learn about LGBTQ+ affirming therapy and the more opportunities they have to work with LGBTQ+ clients, the more competent they felt when working with LGBTQ+ clients.  Godfrey et al. (2006) sought out to determine which aspects of curricula are essential for working effectively with LGBTQ+ clients. They advocate for students to learn about unique strengths and challenges of LGBTQ+ individuals, in addition to ways that LGBTQ+ culture compares to and contrasts with the dominant culture (Godfrey et al., 2006). According to LGBTQ+ clients, the most effective clinicians are those that understand societal prejudice, internalized homophobia, relationship concerns, and community supports as they relate to LGBTQ+ people (Godfrey et al., 2006). Godfrey et   49 al. (2006) recommend that clinicians educate themselves about heterocentrism, heterosexism, negative effects of conversion therapy, and the privileged status that comes with identifying as both heterosexual and cisgender.  In 2013, Bidell used the Sexual Orientation Counselor Competency Scale (SOCCS) self-report tool to determine the impact of an LGBT-affirming counseling course on clinician competency. At the end of the full semester course, Bidell (2013) found that an “LGBT graduate course can significantly improve counseling students’ sexual orientation counselor competency and self-efficacy” (p. 303). Not only did the students significantly improve their competency and self-efficacy, they also scored significantly higher in both areas compared to the control group (Bidell, 2013).  Affirming Therapy in the Coming Out Process The process of coming out is a central theme for many (not all) LGBTQ+ people (APA, 2009; Davies & Neal, 1996). It signifies an individual accepting themselves and feeling comfortable and safe with sharing their sexual and/or gender identity with loved ones (Davies & Neal, 1996). Coming out is critical because it tends to be a culmination of a person’s sexual and/or gender identity exploration process (Alderson, 2013). LGBTQ+ people who are out are more likely to be psychologically healthy compared to those who are not (Alderson, 2013). A major contribution to this difference is likely related to the impact of integrating their LGBTQ+ identity and overcoming internalized homophobia (Van Zyl et al., 2017). LGBTQ+ youth who had come out were found to experience improved overall well-being compared to closeted youth (Kosciw et al., 2015). This improved well-being was also found to last throughout young adulthood (Kosciw et al., 2015). While coming out is a common occurrence, it is a largely individual process that   50 varies widely. Coming out is influenced by many variables, including gender identity, racial identity, ethnic identity, regional identity, physical ability, socioeconomic status, and religious identity. It is also worth noting that coming out as having a non-heterosexual identity can look vastly different from coming out as having a non-cisgender identity. When considering the impact of race and/or ethnicity on the coming out process, one important consideration is that although a member of a minority racial and/or ethnic identity has likely experienced racial prejudice, they are often supported in these experiences by their loved ones. When coming to terms with LGBTQ+ prejudice, that familial and peer support may not be guaranteed (Davies & Neal, 1996). As will be discussed in the section on the role of intersectionality, LGBTQ+ people of color often experience more discrimination than do white LGBTQ+ individuals. So, it is reasonable to consider that LGBTQ+ people of color may rely on support from loved ones even more heavily than do white LGBTQ+ individuals. Another crucial consideration of LGBTQ+ people of color is that for as rare as it is to see LGBTQ+ media representation, it is far rarer to see LGBTQ+ people of color represented in the media. Media representation can also serve to “challenge negative stereotypes” regarding any minority identities (Butler, 2010, p. 88). Youth having these role models and examples of people like them can be a crucial part of acceptance that they are not alone in their identities.  An additional consideration in variations of the coming out process is where the individual is from and/or where they live geographically. As mentioned earlier, LGBTQ+ community centers and events are often exclusive to larger cities and metropolitan areas, though that is slowly changing. In more heavily populated areas, you are more likely to   51 have visible representation of LGBTQ+ people than you are in more rural areas. Much like in media representation, having representation in one’s everyday life can also have a sizeable impact on one’s own sexual and/or gender identity exploration and acceptance. When living in smaller towns, LGBTQ+ people may rarely encounter other LGBTQ+ people unless they visit more metropolitan areas. This is a significant consideration when looking at the feasibility of your client maintaining, expanding, or creating an LGBTQ+ support network. When LGBTQ+ people grow up in less populated areas, they often come out at older ages, if at all (Davies & Neal, 1996).  When considering working with clients in their coming out process, another major factor is how clients perceive and experience their clinicians (Davies & Neal, 1996). The more affirming the clinician, the more likely clients will feel comfortable in discussing and pursuing the coming out process. There are of course many other considerations when working with the coming out process.  One of those considerations is the impact that denial can have on a client coming out. A client may be having gay sexual experiences but may not identify as gay/bisexual/pansexual. If denial is at play, then it is likely that even mentioning coming out would seriously damage rapport. Another concern that presents itself in therapy is that of identity confusion, which is when clients think that they may be LGBTQ+ but they are not satisfied with that prospect (Davies & Neal, 1996). In these situations, the way a clinician responds is critical to the success of providing affirming therapy. This situation presents an opportunity to discuss LGBTQ+ agencies, centers, and events in the area as a way of further introducing a client to what may be some of their first experiences with LGBTQ+ people.    52 While coming out to friends and family can be a relieving and joyous experience, there is a significant possibility that it may produce significant feelings of depression, anxiety, and isolation (Ali & Lambie, 2019). This depression can occur after coming out or in anticipation of how loved ones may react to the news. Oftentimes clients fear that they will lose family support and that their coming out may damage their family relationships for a long period of time. Considering losing the support and love of family is a threatening prospect, and its likelihood should be assessed when clinicians are in the earlier stages of discussing the coming out process. In the most severe cases, this depression can lead to suicidal ideation, suicide attempts, and/or self-destructive behavior (Davies & Neal, 1996). In the face of these issues, clinicians should help their clients identify positive aspects of them identifying as LGBTQ+. While there are of course negative aspects, it is recommended that a focus be placed on positive aspects in order to reduce feelings of depression and increase the likelihood of clients integrating their LGBTQ+ identity. When working with clients during the coming out process, it is crucial for them to have established healthy coping skills and social support (Ali & Lambie, 2019). A strengths-based group counseling intervention was found to be helpful for LGBTQ+ individuals during their coming out process (Ali & Lambie, 2019). Participants mentioned that sharing of information and experiences, modeling, and validation were highlights of the group intervention (Ali & Lambie, 2019). The group was found to be a safe environment for clients to process their identities while feeling a sense of togetherness with others who were also coming out at the same time (Ali & Lambie, 2019). Overall, a strengths-based group therapy intervention was found to be a helpful   53 and positive experience for participants who were going through the coming out process (Ali & Lambie, 2019).   Alderson (2013) found that individuals who were rejected by their families after coming out experienced worse health outcomes compared to those who were accepted by their families. Page (2014) determined that parental rejection has been associated with “maladjustment, risky sexual behavior, increased substance use, victimization, violence, and suicidality” that can last well into adulthood (p. 1). Page (2014) found that familial rejection also increased one’s likelihood of experiencing depression, anxiety, decreased self-esteem, and other mental health symptoms. Goldfried (2001) asserted that parental support served to significantly reduce psychological symptomatology. Bohan (1996) discovered that approximately half of the violence that occurs against LGBTQ+ individuals comes from their own family members. As a result, it is important to consider issues of safety and anticipated reactions when clients think about coming out to their families. Additionally, it is important to discuss what the worst-case scenario would look like in order to further prepare your client for the reality of their coming out to family and loved ones (Alderson, 2013). Johnson et al. (2019) reported that LGBTQ+ youth who have supportive families have better overall psychological well-being compared to LGBTQ+ youth who experience familial rejection.  Ideally, clients will move into a phase of coming out where they have pride in their LGBTQ+ identity. They may reject society’s messages about the normality of heterosexuality and cisgender identities and proceed to embrace their LGBTQ+ support system. It is worth noting here that during this time, clients may also express feelings of anger towards heterosexuals and society at large for the discrimination and prejudice they   54 have experienced. Often, these contrasting feelings of pride and anger can lead to LGBTQ+ activism and an identity as an activist.  Finally, it is hoped that clients will move into a phase where they fully integrate their sexual and/or gender identity into their overarching sense of self (Van Zyl, 2017). Upon having repeated positive experiences with heterosexuals, clients often see that many heterosexuals are not overtly hostile and do not support homophobia, biphobia, and/or transphobia. Clients in this phase often see similarities between themselves and heterosexual and cisgender people while still acknowledging the differences between them. However, it is unreasonable to expect clients to ignore the power differential between themselves and heterosexual, cisgender people.  When working with clients during their coming out process, it is unlikely that you will only encounter cisgender clients. You may work with clients who identify as gender fluid, which “extends beyond behavior and interests to the experience of multiple, and sometimes contradictory, gender identifications” (Clarke et al., 2010, p. 153). As might be expected, these instances can make the coming out process a more complex and at times confusing process.  Another crucial consideration in the coming out process is the fact coming out is never a one-time experience (Butler, 2010). Rather, LGBTQ+ people experience coming out as an ongoing event that continues to occur across the lifespan (Clarke et al., 2010). As a result of the various conditions at play in different contexts of their lives, it is not uncommon for some clients to be out in some contexts and to choose not to disclose their sexual and/or gender identity in others.    55 Whenever clients come out within the context of therapy, Chazin and Klugman (2014) recommend that clinicians communicate acceptance regarding their sexual and/or gender identities, share appreciation of the difficulty associated with coming out, and gather information about their client’s developmental and interpersonal history. The overarching goals of this response are to foster a trusting and collaborative relationship that would guide the rest of treatment. It is also worth noting that a clinician’s acceptance of a client coming out can help clients feel more motivated to come out to others (Chazin & Klugman, 2014).  Role of Intersectionality in LGBTQ+ Affirming Therapy When considering the role that intersectionality plays in the lives of LGBTQ+ individuals and the utilization of affirming therapy, it is also important to consider the impact of having little to no research that includes LGBTQ+ people of color (Clarke et al., 2010). Crenshaw (1989) posited that “no single element of identity, be it race, ethnicity, class, disability, gender, or sexual orientation can truly be understood except in relation to the others” (p. 145). When using one’s intersecting identities to gain a deeper and more holistic understanding of them, Nadal et al. (2015) suggest that clinicians “understand how these identities sometimes conflict with each other and sometimes can even complement each other” (p. 154). Clarke et al. (2010) stated that there were “significant gaps in our knowledge about the lives of BTQ (Bisexual, Transgender, and Queer) people,” and LGBTQ+ people who “experience both heterosexism and social marginalization relating to race, culture, gender, old age, disability, rural isolation, social class, and poverty” (p. 21). Moradi et al. (2010) found a similar lack of visibility when researching studies conducted with gay people of color. Between 1998 to 2007, Huang et   56 al. (2010) found that “only two nationally representative studies were undertaken regarding LGB individuals” (p. 70). Based on this literature review, it is likely that these gaps still exist, especially when considering the lives of LGBTQ+ people of color.   Parmenter et al. (2021) demonstrated that “various co-constructed systems of oppression intersected to further isolate, exclude, and disenfranchise LGBTQ+ people of color from the mainstream white LGBTQ+ community” (p. 9). This furthers the point that focusing on only one cultural identity ignores so many lived experiences of clients, especially LGBTQ+ people of color (Parmenter et al., 2021). In the context of therapy, LGBTQ+ people of color reported that clinician recognition of intersectionality allowed them to “feel seen in a holistic manner” (Parmenter et al., 2021, p. 9). It was also determined that “connecting with other LGBTQ+ people of color” was associated with improved overall well-being for LGBTQ+ people of color (Parmenter et al., 2021, p. 9).   Inclusion of LGBTQ+ people of color in research is crucial because there can be significant differences in their experiences compared to white LGBTQ+ individuals. Many studies assert that gay people of color have difficulty “integrating two minority identities” (Alderson, 2013, p. 41). Flores et al. (2009) found that African and Latino American men attracted to other men were less likely to identify as gay and more likely to report internalized homophobia compared with gay white men. When comparing rates of coming out between white people and people of color, people of color are less likely to be openly LGBTQ+ to their parents (Grov et al., 2006). Bowleg et al. (2003) determined that Black lesbians reported experiences of triple jeopardy due to the stress they experienced due to having Black, lesbian, and female identities. Interestingly, Rostosky   57 et al. (2008) reported that almost half of the participants asserted that they experienced more stress due to their sexual identities rather than their racial identities.   As might be expected, there are several studies supporting the fact that LGBTQ+ people of color experience even greater health disparities compared with white LGBTQ+ individuals. Camarena and Rutter (2015) reported that African American LGBTQ+ individuals are vastly overrepresented in HIV/AIDS rates. As a result, it is crucial to have discussions regarding safer sexual experiences with all clients, especially with LGBTQ+ people of color. Compared to white LGBTQ+ individuals, LGBTQ+ people of color are “exposed to greater heterosexist stigma” (Muraco, 2014, p. 26). When working with LGBTQ+ people of color, Balsam et al. (2011) and Camarena and Rutter (2015) recommend discussing minority stress in order to reduce psychological distress and sexual health disparities. Similarly, Camarena and Rutter (2015) suggest that said psychological distress could be minimized using concrete coping skills.   When considering theoretical underpinnings to utilize when working with LGBTQ+ people of color, Camarena and Rutter (2015) advocate for the use of feminist theory because it emphasizes client empowerment and addresses the impact of societal oppression. Feminist approaches analyze experiences of power and oppression in the lives of clients and work collaboratively to challenge oppressive environments, which includes analyzing the power dynamics between the clinician and the client (Camarena & Rutter, 2015). Once this analysis has begun, an important next step is to discuss systemic underpinnings of clients’ distress and to help clients feel a greater sense of power in their newly integrated identities (Camarena & Rutter, 2015). Additionally, it is important to analyze messages regarding gender roles, power, and privilege that clients have   58 internalized. Camarena and Rutter (2015) also suggest that narrative and cognitive interventions could be integrated into a clinician’s feminist theory work when working with LGBTQ+ clients of color. “The power of the intersectional lens is the way it frames individuals’ experiences of identity and power as complex, dynamic, subjective, and specific, rather than as single-axis, static, autonomous, and generalized” (Addison & Coolhart, 2015, p. 440). Additionally, it is important to consider how the various identities of clinicians interact and overlap with those of LGBTQ+ clients. Addison and Coolhart (2015) advocate for “looking at the intersections of multiple identities” (p. 442) in order to better conceptualize the experiences of LGBTQ+ clients in therapy.   In 2013, Bowleg conducted a qualitative research study with 12 Black gay and bisexual men regarding their experiences with intersectionality. One participant explained that it would be difficult to separate his race, gender, and sexual identity because he does not experience life through exclusive and distinct identities (Bowleg, 2013). The researchers characterized the importance of intersectionality by stating “focusing on a single category obscures the depth of understanding provided by that category’s intersection with other categories” (Bowleg, 2013, p. 758). Interestingly, 83% of participants ranked their identity as Black as their primary identity rather than their gender or sexual identity (Bowleg, 2013). It is important to keep in mind that cultural identities are socially constructed via power relations and can differ significantly across geographic locations. One participant noted that “negative stereotypes associated with Black men often overlapped with those held of gay people” (Bowleg, 2013, p. 760), such as promiscuity and incapable of sustaining long-term romantic relationships.    59  Meyer (2015) conducted extensive research in order to determine what experiences LGBTQ+ individuals were having with violence and the impact that intersecting minorities can have in violent experiences. He found that “racism, sexism, and social class inequality continue to affect what individuals encounter in their daily lives, including forms of violence” (Meyer, 2015, p. 4). History has demonstrated that cases of violence involving white LGBTQ+ individuals have received significantly more media coverage than instances involving LGBTQ+ people of color (Meyer, 2015). This is especially concerning given the fact that LGBTQ+ people of color experience violence at higher rates than white LGBTQ+ individuals (Meyer, 2015). Meyer (2015) also demonstrated that LGBTQ+ individuals of lower socioeconomic status were more likely to experience violence compared to their higher socioeconomic status peers. Overall, Meyer (2015) reported that queer people are “privileged and disadvantaged in significant ways based on their social position” (p. 13).   In 2011, Balsam et al. (2011) created the LGBT People of Color Microaggressions Scale based on a three-phase, mixed method empirical research study. They were able to assess the frequency and distress caused by microaggressions experienced by LGBTQ+ people of color (Balsam et al., 2011). Through factor analysis, three domains of microaggressions were found: “racism within LGBT communities, heterosexism within racial/ethnic communities, and racial/ethnic discrimination in dating and close relationships” (Balsam et al., 2011, p. 171). Results indicated that microaggressions were associated with depression and perceived stress and that different types of microaggressions led to different effects (Balsam et al., 2011).    60 When providing LGBTQ+ affirming therapy, Haldeman (2007) emphasizes the fact that some LGBTQ+ individuals may struggle with marginalization within the LGBTQ+ community due to their racial, ethnic, or socioeconomic identities. This should be kept in mind especially when considering that not every LGBTQ+ client will be able/willing to become part of alternative sexual identity communities.  Minority Stress Model & Resilience  In 1995, Meyer created the minority stress hypothesis, which suggests that individuals who possess minority identities may experience increased stress and mental health symptoms due to the discriminatory and prejudicial experiences that take place when living in the dominant culture. This hypothesis includes three major components: internalized homophobia, stigma or expectations associated with discrimination, and encountering experiences that reinforce anticipated discrimination (Meyer, 1995). Breslow et al. (2015), Muraco (2014), and Westcott (2020) found that experiencing discrimination, prejudice, and victimization are all associated with increased psychological distress, substance abuse, and suicidality. Another common experience that increases minority stress is the devaluation of same-sex couples and same-sex parents (Muraco, 2014). Lindstrom et al. (2020) also demonstrated that sexual minorities have a storied history of experiencing more stress and marginalization than do heterosexual individuals. Relating to LGBTQ+ affirming care, the APA (2009) found that the minority stress model “provides a framework for considering the social context of stress, distress, coping, resilience, acceptance, and goals of treatment” (p. 17).   In 2018, Smalley et al. addressed the importance of LGBTQ+ health, including the impact of minority stress, barriers to accessing care, and evidence-based approaches   61 for improving health care while also reducing minority stress. Their research indicated that GSM individuals are less likely to seek and access ongoing health care due to “experience-based fear and mistrust of the medical community” (Smalley et al., 2018, p. 4). This fear is affirmed by the fact that, though the Affordable Care Act provided federal protection of gender identity-based discrimination, this protection only applies to institutions that receive federal funding (Smalley et al., 2018). “56% of sexual minority adults and 70% of transgender individuals report experiencing discrimination in health care settings” (Smalley et al., 2018, p. 18). As LGBTQ+ people endure negative health care experiences, they are more likely to avoid seeking care in the future (Smalley et al., 2018). Smalley et al. (2018) reported that over 67% of GSM individuals reported experiencing discrimination in their personal lives and 15-43% experienced it in their professional lives. Even worse, transgender individuals reported that 90% of them had experienced discrimination at work (Smalley et al., 2018). These experiences of discrimination are clearly experiences that can increase minority stress and decrease overall psychological functioning and well-being.   Protective factors related to minority stress have also been explored. Research findings indicate that people who report consistent social support experienced reduced minority stress compared to those without social support (Job & Williams, 2020; Muraco, 2014). The APA (2009) asserted that one’s collective identity can reduce the impact of minority stress and is more effective at reducing this impact compared to individual factors like coping skills, resilience, and optimism. Job and Williams (2020) determined that reaching out to social supports during times of distress also improved physical health. Interventions created for use with romantic relationships were found to increase   62 relationship satisfaction and mitigate the impact of minority stressors (Job & Williams, 2020).   Resilience is an emerging area in mental health research that has grown in popularity over recent years. Bartos and Langdridge (2019) researched the intersection between resilience and LGBTQ+ research by conducting a meta-analysis of 21 qualitative studies about the hardships faced by the LGBTQ+ community. They produced a unique and insightful definition of resilience as it pertains to LGBTQ+ individuals: “resilience is thus not about a return, but instead an adaptive innovation in living in the face of ongoing social threat and stress” (Bartos & Langdridge, 2019, p. 243). This clarification was provided as a response to common views of resilience as being able to ‘bounce back’ after a stressful experience. Additionally, Bartos and Langdridge (2019) uncovered countless stories of LGBTQ+ resilience that “involve an active sense of agency” (p. 244). Examples were also given as to what innovative resilience looks like for LGBTQ+ individuals and included the concept of families of choice and relationship diversity (Bartos & Langdridge, 2019).   Woodford et al. (2018) reported that resilience in LGBTQ+ college students was associated with decreased risk for suicide. Conversely, students with lower levels of resilience were more likely to experience interpersonal microaggressions and to conceptualize these experiences as more damaging than individuals with higher levels of resilience (Woodford et al., 2018). Breslow et al. (2015) determined that resilience was highly associated with a lower degree of psychological distress. Overall, these results indicate that increasing resilience among LGBTQ+ students can lower their risk for experiencing depression and suicide attempts (Woodford et al., 2018).   63  In 2019, Schmitz and Tyler interviewed 46 LGBTQ+ young adults about their experiences with resilience through challenging experiences. Results revealed that resilience-building experiences were associated with improved mental health and safe coping strategies (Schmitz & Tyler, 2019). Participants reported how important it was for them to establish or maintain their own self-confidence in their sexual and/or gender identity (Schmitz & Tyler, 2019). Many individuals shared that they experienced a high degree of support and acceptance on their college campuses, which improved their resilience and responses to challenging identity-related situations (Schmitz & Tyler, 2019).  Another emerging area in LGBTQ+ mental health research is the importance of resilience in living through the current COVID-19 pandemic. Gonzalez et al. (2021) interviewed 129 LGBTQ+ individuals who shared their experiences with resilience throughout the pandemic. This research is especially important because of the fact that LGBTQ+ people have been disproportionately impacted by health epidemics in the past, namely AIDS (Gonzalez et al., 2021). Participants reported that “overcoming difficult experiences, radical acceptance, self-reliance, and community support helped them build resilience and use their resilience to better navigate the COVID-19 pandemic” (Gonzalez et al., 2021, p. 139). LGBTQ+ participants also indicated that their experiences of turning inward and enjoying time with themselves as part of being marginalized may have allowed them to be less negatively affected by social distancing (Gonzalez et al., 2021). Another common finding was that LGBTQ+ people continued to find community online throughout the pandemic, which was a consistent part of their lives prior to the pandemic   64 since online communities are “safer alternatives to in-person spaces, particularly for people who might not be publicly out” (Gonzalez et al., 2021, p. 140).  Discussion Whenever people identified as LGBTQ+ in the past, many times the response by religious and conservative individuals was for them to engage in conversion therapy. However, studies conducted over the past 25 years have indicated that conversion therapy has been repeatedly associated with increased depression, anxiety, and suicidality and decreased self-esteem, self-worth, and overall psychological well-being. As of February 2022, there are still no studies that empirically support the use of conversion therapy. Studies that have supported the use of conversion therapy in the past have been found to involve significant methodological flaws. Overall, the methodological flaws of conversion therapy studies include an inability to make causal claims due to internal validity concerns, lack of construct validity, issues with conclusion validity, use of unreliable measures, small and narrowly stratified samples, and limited generalizability of findings (APA, 2009). Research on conversion therapy does not support the ability of such interventions to change one’s sexual attractions (APA, 2009). The majority of research on conversion therapy is based on a mainly white male sample of adults from strongly religious and conservative backgrounds and is thus not generalizable to LGBTQ+ individuals as a whole (APA, 2009).  Two common concerns that persist in the lives of LGBTQ+ individuals are institutionalized and internalized homophobia. Institutionalized homophobia includes negative stereotypes about being LGBTQ+, a lack of LGBTQ+ education in schools, and a lack of LGBTQ+ media representation. Internalized homophobia involves the hate one   65 experiences in the world about LGBTQ+ individuals being turned towards oneself. It has been associated with social isolation, anxiety, suicide, and low self-esteem (Alderson, 2013; Hill, 2009).   In terms of psychological and emotional health of LGBTQ+ individuals, having a minority sexual and/or gender identity has been associated with significantly higher levels of overall psychological distress (Hinrichs & Donaldson, 2017). This includes disproportionately high rates of anxiety, depression, suicidality, and substance use (Hinrichs & Donaldson, 2017; Lindstrom et al., 2020). These concerns help explain why so many LGBTQ+ people seek out mental health services, significantly more so than heterosexual and cisgender individuals.   Unlike CBT, Client-Centered Therapy, and Psychodynamic Therapy, LGBTQ+ affirming therapy is not its own system of therapy. Rather, it is a way of conducting therapy and of conceptualizing clients in a more culturally-informed and open-minded way. Key conditions of LGBTQ+ affirming therapy include a strong therapeutic alliance, respect, validation, and openness to discuss concerns regarding discrimination, oppression, and homo/transphobia. Affirming therapy involves establishing feelings of safety and security, helping clients to love and accept themselves, and helping clients integrate their LGBTQ+ identity into their overarching sense of self. In terms of empirically-based interventions, CBT, Positive Psychology, and strengths-based approaches at the individual and group levels have demonstrated successful outcomes. Since most clinicians will end up working with LGBTQ+ clients, they should receive education on doing so, just like they would for working with clients of other diverse   66 cultural identities. Clinician training and education has been found to increase clinician confidence and competence in clinical settings (Bidell, 2013).   A common concern when working with LGBTQ+ clients is coming out, especially because it is a process that occurs across the lifespan. Coming out is important to many LGBTQ+ people because it is associated with improved psychological functioning and relationships with loved ones. When working with LGBTQ+ clients in their coming out process, it is important to establish effective coping skills and strong social support (Ali & Lambie, 2019). Just as important, clinicians should prepare their clients for the possibility that they will not experience positive reactions when coming out to their loved ones. These situations are certainly ones where having a strong support system can have a protective effect.  Another important consideration when working with LGBTQ+ clients is the role of intersectionality or intersecting cultural identities. Clients do not experience life in separate identities, so why should clinicians treat clients as if they do? Race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, region, and sexual and gender identity combine to create an individual’s lived experiences. Sometimes one’s identities give them conflicting messages and sometimes various combinations of identities can make it difficult for people to find spaces where they can fully be themselves. The sooner this is realized and put into action on the part of the clinician, the better.   Finally, the minority stress model helps to explain how and why people with minority identities experience increased mental health symptoms as a result of experiences with prejudice and discrimination (Meyer, 1995). This model includes internalized homophobia, expectations of discriminatory experiences, and experiences   67 that reinforce one’s expectations of discrimination (Meyer, 1995). Additionally, the minority stress model helps to explain many of the barriers that LGBTQ+ clients face in seeking and receiving healthcare. Resilience has been established as a protective factor for minority identity individuals because it is associated with improved mental health and an increased likelihood of conceptualizing negative experiences in more manageable and less harmful ways (Breslow et al., 2015).  Although there have been many recent gains in acceptance and legal protections for LGBTQ+ individuals, there is still a long way to go before true equality is fully achieved. Since discrimination, prejudice, and microaggressions are still part of everyday life for LGBTQ+ people and their mental health concerns continue to be a significant concern, it is imperative that the mental health field does its best to provide much-needed support. Recommendations for Using Affirming Therapy in Clinical Practice Barriers to Accessing Healthcare • In order to address individual barriers to accessing health care, it is recommended that providers adopt inclusive policies and include sexual and gender identity in their nondiscrimination policies. GSM individuals should also be included in basic health care coverage so that their needs can be met (Smalley et al., 2018). • When considering systemic barriers to accessing care, it is recommended that LGBTQ+ clinical and cultural competency be included in education for all health professionals, including continuing education experiences (Smalley et al., 2018). • In order to address environmental barriers to accessing health care, it is recommended that bathrooms should be gender neutral, materials displaying GSM people should be included, and documentation should include space on patient forms to indicate a wide variety of sexual identities, gender identities, and relationship statuses (Smalley et al., 2018). Client Conceptualization • When working with LGBTQ+ clients, it is crucial that providers consider the societal and institutional context that their clients have experienced (Smalley et al., 2018).  • Use client strengths to balance your understanding of the negative effects of marginalization and discrimination experienced by the LGBTQ+ community (Westcott, 2020).     90 Clinician Focused • Clinicians have an obligation to explore their own sexual identity and to feel secure in every part of their sexual identity prior to working effectively with LGBTQ+ clients (Davies & Neal, 1996). • Explore your own attitudes towards individuals of varying sexual and gender identities as a clinician before working with LGBTQ+ clients (Hinrichs & Donaldson, 2017). • It is crucial for clinicians to be familiar with various resources and events for LGBTQ+ clients in their area so they can recommend various groups and activities, if necessary (Hinrichs & Donaldson, 2017). • Use open-minded language that does not make any assumptions about one’s sexual or gender identities when working with clients during sessions (Hinrichs & Donaldson, 2017).  • Clinicians should address their own personal biases regarding sexual and gender identities prior to working with LGBTQ+ clients (Cramer et al., 2008).  • Training interventions for clinicians should focus on clinicians’ attitudes, especially regarding internalized homophobia and heterosexism (Alessi et al., 2016). • Avoid assuming that issues of sexual and/or gender identity (such as coming out or transitioning) are an LGBTQ+ client’s primary presenting concerns (Chazin & Klugman, 2014).  • Clinicians should consider the role that advocacy can play when working with LGBTQ+ clients. This involves assisting clients in identifying societal issues that   91 they would like to change, supporting those actions, teaching coping skills for issues that clients cannot change, and being aware of resources that are available (Pachankis & Goldfried, 2013). Discrimination, Prejudice, & Oppression • Clinicians should be aware of the reality that many LGBTQ+ clients have experienced some form of oppression related to their sexual and/or gender identity and the impact of that oppression varies considerably (Davies & Neal, 1996). • “Show willingness to discuss and point out ways that homophobia, heterosexism, and transphobia, along with other forms of discrimination and prejudice, affect the client’s mental health and intersect with current stressors” (Hinrichs & Donaldson, 2017, p. 952). • Research the sociopolitical oppression that marks the history of LGBTQ+ people and use that context to aid the accuracy of your clients’ conceptualizations (Moradi & Budge, 2018).  • Consider the fact that LGBTQ+ people as a group have experienced a significant amount of oppression over time at the individual, group, systemic, and institutional levels (Alderson, 2013).  • If indicated, discuss ways in which oppression has impacted the lives of LGBTQ+ clients (Alderson, 2013).  • When working with transgender clients, clinicians should aim to address the ways in which normative gender society has impacted their lives (Benson, 2013).    92  Environmental • Use inclusive and non-heterosexist language in verbal and written communication in your work as an affirming clinician (Alderson, 2013). • Use intake forms that do not assume one’s sexual or gender identities and include a space for clients to list theirs if they are not listed as options on the forms (Hinrichs & Donaldson, 2017). • Provide gender neutral bathrooms within your clinical practice (Hinrichs & Donaldson, 2017).  • Including space for client strengths on intake forms can allow clients to focus on their resources as opposed to their deficits. This space could include specific questions, such as: “What are your greatest strengths?” “What strengths do you see in yourself in terms of how you connect with others?” and “What abilities or qualities contribute to your resilience?” (Westcott, 2020). Group Focused • Consider setting up a peer support group of LGBTQ+ clients for a wide variety of presenting concerns, depending on trends in client needs (Lloyd et al., 2021). • When groups are provided, emphasize the role that intersectionality plays in identifying as LGBTQ+. This opens the door for discussions about how each participant’s lived experiences differ even with a shared sexual identity and/or gender identity (Lloyd et al., 2021).   93 • When planning LGBTQ+ therapy groups, consider including discussions about how participants respond to oppression and discrimination in their daily lives (Lloyd et al., 2021).  Identity • If indicated, clinicians should discuss and question assumptions about identifying as LGBTQ+ (Davies & Neal, 1996). • “Staff should ask all clients about sexual orientation and gender identity. This prevents us from making assumptions” (Hinrichs & Donaldson, 2017, p. 951). • Include question about pronouns on intake paperwork (Hinrichs & Donaldson, 2017). • Ask open-ended questions regarding the impact that gender, sexual identity, race, socioeconomic status, and other identities have had on your clients (Addison & Coolhart, 2015).  • As clinicians, strive to keep in mind the fact that LGBTQ+ individuals represent people across the spectrums of age, socioeconomic status, gender identity, ethnicity, race, and other cultural identities and the impact that such diversity has on them (Moradi & Budge, 2018).  • In order to start work with clients who struggle with internalized homophobia, clinicians are encouraged to provide an open-minded and nonjudgmental place for their clients to pursue identity exploration (Hinrichs & Donaldson, 2017). • Consider LGBTQ+ clients as unique individuals and take care to not generalize their experiences based on your knowledge about the LGBTQ+ community (Smalley et al., 2018).   94 • Keep in mind that clients are constantly impacted by multiple intersecting cultural identities that may conflict with each other at times (Smalley et al., 2018).  Interventions • When working with LGBTQ+ clients, it is important to balance openness with empirically informed interventions (Cerbone, 2020). • If primary presenting concerns include guilt and/or shame as a result of identifying as LGBTQ+, consider focusing on constructive ways to cope with these feelings. Establishing and maintaining supportive environments may also be helpful in these situations (Bybee, 2009). • Consider using expressive writing interventions when presenting concerns include stress, openness about sexual and/or gender identity, or internalized heterosexism (Smalley et al., 2018). • Clinicians should emphasize resilience in sessions with LGBTQ+ clients, especially when their presenting concerns are related to depression and/or suicidality (Woodford et al., 2018).  • Apply LGBTQ+ affirmative techniques and beliefs in your work with all clients, not a select few (Moradi & Budge, 2018). • Utilize positive affirmations with clients in order to reduce the negative impact of heterosexism (Love et al., 2014).  • Discuss the possibility of collaboratively establishing an individualized values system to further determine what being LGBTQ+ means to your client as an individual (Davies & Neal, 1996).     95 Support Systems • LGBTQ+ clients should be encouraged to establish, maintain, or expand an LGBTQ+ support system (Davies & Neal, 1996). • Discuss the importance of your LGBTQ+ clients becoming involved in LGBTQ+ community activities and events (Davies & Neal, 1996). • Use social support systems to increase clients’ psychological well-being (APA, 2009). • The use of mutual support groups is critical in reducing minority stress and feelings of isolation (APA, 2009). Therapeutic Relationship • Clinicians are encouraged to work with their LGBTQ+ clients to identify stereotypes of non-heterosexual/non-cisgender people and proceed to undo the negative connotations that are associated with such stereotypes (Davies & Neal, 1996). • Consider establishing a companion/peer-type of relationship with your clients in order to communicate that your clients are not inferior to you as the clinician (Davies & Neal, 1996). • Use your power as a clinician to affirm the thoughts, feelings, and emotions that are reported by your LGBTQ+ clients (Davies & Neal, 1996). • Make sure to check in with clients in order to maintain rapport and catch any mistakes that may have transpired throughout client interactions (Smalley et al., 2018).     96 Appendix C Glossary Biphobia – Negative beliefs towards people who identify as bisexual that present as anxiety, aversion, discomfort, disgust, and/or fear of bisexual individuals. Bisexual – An individual who is sexually and emotionally attracted to both men and women. Conversion therapy – Attempts to change one’s sexual identity from LGBQ+ to heterosexual. Gay – Men who are sexually and emotionally attracted to other men. Genderfluid – An individual who does not identify with a distinct and fixed gender identity. Heterosexism – A belief that heterosexuality is the only normal lived experience and that it is superior to any other type of sexual identity. Furthermore, these individuals believe that everyone should be heterosexual. Heterosexual – An individual who is sexually and emotionally attracted to the opposite sex/gender identity. Homophobia – Negative beliefs towards lesbians and gay men that present as anxiety, aversion, discomfort, disgust, and/or fear of lesbians and gay men. Homosexual – See Gay Institutionalized homophobia – An organization’s failure to provide appropriate service to people as a result of their sexual identity. It can be seen in attitudes and actions that lead to discrimination through prejudice, ignorance, and stereotyping.   97 Internalized homophobia – Negative beliefs about oneself as a lesbian or gay man that exists as a result of internalizing the negative beliefs that others and society and general have towards lesbians and gay men.  Intersectionality – When people are conceptualized as multiple identities occurring simultaneously in order to produce a coherent experience, rather than considering these different identities to constitute an additive model of identity. Lesbian – Women who are sexually and emotionally attracted to other women.  Nonbinary – A person who does not identify exclusively as male or female. They may identify as male and female, somewhere between male and female, or completely unrelated to male and/or female.  Pansexual – An individual who can be emotionally, romantically, or sexually attracted to any gender identity.  Polyamory – Individuals having more than one intimate partner at the same time, with all parties being aware of the situation. These partners may possess emotional and/or sexual relationships with each other, depending on the situation.  Queer – A multifaceted term that reflects LGBTQ+ people and may be a representation of one’s sexual and/or gender identities rather than one subscribing to labels such as ‘bisexual,’ ‘lesbian,’ or ‘gay’. Sexual identity – One’s sexuality and form of attraction to others, which is a significant component of one’s coherent sense of self.  Transgender – An individual whose gender identity is not aligned with the gender that they were assigned at birth. This term does not, however, reflect one’s sexual identity (ex. gay, lesbian, bisexual).
title: Pride: A Review of LGBTQ+ Affirming Therapy Techniques and Recommendations for Clinical Practice
abstract: Despite recent advances in legal protections for and increases in social acceptability towards LGBTQ+ individuals, they continue to experience widespread prejudice and discrimination and seek therapy more often than their heterosexual counterparts as a result. As more and more LGBTQ+ people sought out therapeutic services, psychological research in the field of LGBTQ+ affirming therapy began to develop in order to meet these needs. Although the number of articles and studies conducted in this field has grown exponentially since the start of the 21st century, a sizeable gap between research and application remains. Research often provides vague suggestions without discussing specific clinical recommendations. Until discussion shifts to emphasize the practical aspect of LGBTQ+ affirming therapy, the mental health needs of this large and diverse group of people will not be met. Therefore, the major goal of this project is to review the intersection of mental health and LGBTQ+ people over time and conclude with specific recommendations for providing LGBTQ+ affirmative care across a variety of presenting concerns and treatment settings. It is worth noting that LGBTQ+ affirming therapy is not a specific theoretical orientation or form of treatment on its own. Rather, it is a way of providing therapeutic treatment that takes into consideration the history of LGBTQ+ individuals, the impact of intersectionality, unique individual experiences, and affirms that nobody is less than anybody else, regardless of their sexual identity and/or gender identity. The cultural identities of our clients should be praised, encouraged, and used to inform how we provide mental health services. These conditions represent the heart of LGBTQ+ affirming therapy, which has the potential to have a significant positive impact on countless individuals who need our help as clinicians
